turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Neo-impressionism.
turn.1: What is the Myth of the South in relation to Neo- impressionism?
turn.2: By setting his pastorals in the south, Signac followed the literary examples of Stendhal and Guy de Maupassant, who linked the region with liberty.
turn.3: Can you tell me what that means?
turn.4: Stendhal "described the south as a place of freedom where the worst faults of capitalist society were less entrenched than in the north." Stendhal also saw the South as a connection to other "Latin" countries who are "outside the civilized societies' concern for money." This movement's peak years lasted about five years (1886–1891), but did not end with Georges Seurat's death in 1891.
turn.6: Impressionism continued to evolve and expand over the next decade with even more distinctive characteristics.
turn.7: What are some of the characteristics?
turn.8: Incorporation of political and social ideas, especially anarchism, started showing prominence.
turn.9: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.10: After Seurat's death by diphtheria and his friend Albert Dubois-Pillet's by smallpox in the previous year, the Neo-impressionists began to change and strengthen their image through social and political alliances.
turn.12: They forged links to the anarcho-communists movement and through this, many more young artists were attracted to this "blend of social and artistic theory".
